urn:contentItem:5W6K-K051-JB20-G4CD-00000-00Manufactured Scandal; Donald Trump Talks About The Boeing Controversy; The Iran Conflict, Taxes, and President Trump's TV and Social Media Habits; Linda McMahon Weighs In On The 2020 Election And Her Time In President Trump's Cabinet; The Downfall Of San Francisco; Another Democrat Jumps Into The 2020 Race2019-05-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:08:31ZLexisNexisTHE NEXT REVOLUTION9:00 PM ESTCharlie Kirk; Linda McMahonNEWSInternational052601cb.265Manufactured Scandal; Donald Trump Talks About The Boeing Controversy; The Iran Conflict, Taxes, and President Trump's TV and Social Media Habits; Linda McMahon Weighs In On The 2020 Election And Her Time In President Trump's Cabinet; The Downfall Of San Francisco; Another Democrat Jumps Into The 2020 RaceSteve Hilton; Sara Carter

STEVE HILTON, FOX NEWS HOST, THE NEXT REVOLUTION: Good evening, everyone, and welcome to THE NEXT REVOLUTION. I'm Steve Hilton and this is the home of positive populism, pro-worker, pro-family, pro-community.

Tonight, we'll bring you more from my conversation at the White House with President Trump -- a part of it that we couldn't quite squeeze into last week's show. Plus an exclusive interview with legendary wrestling entrepreneur and until very recently member of the Trump Cabinet, Linda McMahon.

But tonight I want to start with three letters that just about sum up how I've been feeling. No doubt you, too, as I watched with increasing disbelief this week -- the idiotic, infantile, irresponsible antics of the Democrats in Washington and their lackeys in the establishment state media -- F-F-S. That's what I found myself yelling at the television all week F- F-S.

I'm not allowed to spell it out, but if you don't know what it means, you can look it up. That's what I felt when I saw every ludicrous and melodramatic cynical statement, "Oh for F's sake, Pelosi, what are you talking about? Cover up?" Cover up of what? Your own precious Mueller found no crime. For F's sake, Nadler, you're the one holding the Constitution in contempt. Do you even understand what the separation of powers is? Do you care?

What do they even mean impeach the President? Impeach him for what? Winning an election they thought was theirs by right? What is it exactly that they want to investigate? What do they want to get to the bottom of with their endless spurious subpoenas and hearings? The bottom of the barrel? They're already there.

In all the hours wasted on this, hours when we could be talking about real things that affect the real lives of real Americans, not a single person, not the politicians, not the news anchors, not the pundits, none of them spend a single second talking about anything of actual substance that might justify all this manufactured scandal.

It's all about the process -- the political theater. The Washington D.C., political and media establishment have lost their minds. They are consumed with our own pathetic psychodrama, one that is utterly irrelevant to the rest of the country, but which has foisted on us anyway. What is the point of any of this except to indulge the demented rage of the resistance fanatics, outdoing each other in shrieking at President Trump?

If there's any justice, we would kick the lot of them and replace them with normal people who can calmly work with each other and the President to get things done.

I sent out a tweet last week which seemed to strike a chord. So here it is, again. "Nancy Pelosi is a disingenuous charlatan, throws around Watergate-style cover-up accusations then blames Trump for not being cooperative. She is recklessly undermining faith in our democracy institutions and for what? To pander to her base. She is the one who should be impeached."

Right? Allow me to elaborate. All of this madness will come back to haunt Pelosi and Nadler and Schiff and Maxine Waters and all the rest of them.

The fury of the half of the country whose votes for this President are being scorned on a daily basis by Democrats who refuse to accept the result of the 2016 election and want to overturn it through undemocratic means, the fury of those millions of Americans, it will be visited on the Democrats that I can tell you.

People will not forget the way these self-righteous tyrants behaved. Vengeance will come. If impeachment is now the way to pursue political differences, all right then, let's impeach Pelosi and Nadler. They're doing more damage to our democracy than Donald Trump has ever done.

If total all out investigation is now the chosen tactic to obstruct political opponents, all right, then let's make sure it's applied with equal force to the Democrats. Let's get Nancy Pelosi's tax returns and her husband's while we're at it, and Maxine Waters' bank statements, that'll be fun considering she was once found to be the most corrupt Member of Congress.

Speaking of corruption, don't forget Jerry Nadler. He is up to his neck in it with a decades' long track record of taking money from businesses where he has a clear conflict of interest.

Let's get the Southern District of New York on to him. But we've got to pay it forward, too. One day, there will be another Democratic President and that person, whoever they are, must be crippled right out of the gate by the full weight of investigatory power. No honeymoon, no cooperation, just resistance, obstruction and vilification. That must be the fate of the next Democratic President. It's only fair.

President Trump says this should never happen to another President again; well, that is certainly magnanimous of him. But I think it needs qualification. He is right about the long term, but before we move on, before we return to normal, a debt must be paid by the Democrats. They must go through the exact same process they've put this President through, it's only fair. It's what justice demands.

And then, once they have received a taste of their own medicine, once the Democratic debt has been repaid, perhaps then we can return to a more civilized state of affairs.

Tell me what you think of that @SteveHiltonX and @NextRevFNC.

Now, let's meet our guests for tonight. Fox News contributor Sara Carter, and Turning Point USA founder, Charlie Kirk, who is also the host of the fantastic new "Charlie Kirk Podcast."

CHARLIE KIRK, FOUNDER, TURNING POINT USA: That's correct.

HILTON: Very good. Okay, so I don't know, I'm steamed up about everything. I think half the country is, too. What do you think?

SARA CARTER, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: I think it's fantastic what you said. I was talking to someone today who had said the same thing. Let's just put everything out on the line, put all the cards on the table. Let's investigate the Democrats, too.

If they want to investigate President Trump, let's not just stop with them, Steve. Let's not just stop with them. Let's investigate their families, their children, their connections, how did they handle money? Did they meet people while they were in office?

How is it possible that people like Maxine Waters come into office with a relatively normal bank account and leave with millions of dollars? Or Nancy Pelosi and her business dealings with her husband?

So let's just put the cards out on the table. They want to investigate Trump. Let's investigate every single one of them and their children and any family members that live with them and any business dealings that they have overseas.

KIRK: Speaking of their children, Hunter Biden, I mean, under this sort of microscope that they have put our friend, Donald Trump, Jr. under for taking a singular meeting of which nothing resulted back in June of 2016. Let's put that microscope of 1/100 under Hunter Biden.

And you've covered this brilliantly, Steve. You look at what their family did to this country, to sell our interest to our greatest enemy, China, so they could line their own pockets. Let the investigations begin now.

Republicans have the Senate. There could be investigation starting about how Nancy Pelosi had met with Bashar Al-Assad's father back in 2007 ...

CARTER: That's right.

KIRK: ... for foreign inclusion. You want to talk about all of this foreign collusion? Boy, are they going to go down a very dangerous path.

HILTON: Charlie, you're right, and sorry, Charlie, to cut you off, but I mean, that's such a great point about the Biden's in China, because it shows you how partisan this whole thing is.

KIRK: Yes.

HILTON: If they really cared about democracy and the Constitution and doing things the proper way and holding the Executive to account --

KIRK: Absolutely.

HILTON: They would absolutely be investigating that Biden family connection with China.

CARTER: Biden family connections with China, Hillary Clinton's connections with China, with Ukraine, with others with Russia. Let's look at all of it.

I mean, we seem to forget that Bill Clinton -- and I bring this up over and over again from Renaissance Capital Bank, which is basically run by the FSB.

KIRK: Yes, half a million dollars.

CARTER: Yes, which is basically run by Russian spies, got half a million dollars to speak. To speak about what? He was supporting the Uranium One deal back then in 2010. This is just crazy. So let's do it. Let's put the cards on the table. I think the Democrats would agree. They want full honesty.

That's what they said. They want everything out in the public. Let's get their taxes going back six years. Let's investigate. You know what? Let's go one step further, Steve. Let's find out about all the #MeToo money, all the hush money in Congress.

KIRK: $17 million.

CARTER: Yes, in Congress that was paid out and find out who those congressional representatives were. Let's just -- let's just clean it all out.

KIRK: So Steve, you really struck a chord with me, because I'm hearing a lot of Republicans say we have to move on and forgiveness is a virtue of which I tried to have, but I'm not there yet. I want justice for what that they've put this President through.

HILTON: That's right.

KIRK: And maybe I'll get to a place where we're ready to move on, but not right now. Because these people gallivant around, and they virtue signal towards this President. He has been the most transparent, most successful President of our lifetime.

We know exactly where he is, the meetings that he has. Everything is so transparent with him, and then they're the ones that are saying that he is engaging in a cover-up. Steve, I totally agree that we need to now investigate the investigators, but hold the very same people ...

CARTER: Absolutely.

KIRK: ... that have been preaching against this administration to this standard of foreign corruption and influence.

HILTON: Yes. That's why I am so intrigued because I felt this week when, you know, I mean, we are going to talk about it later the interview I had with President Trump last Sunday. You know, he is talking about policy, serious issues, China -- the debate was a serious debate.

And then immediately, it's the Democrats that are back on to this ridiculous farce of investigations. And I just -- for me, it was like a kind of radicalizing moment. It reminded me of the Kavanaugh hearings, actually. We just saw the true partisanship of what they're doing.

And I thought, "Right, we've got to fight back." And exactly as you say, and that's why I made the point. You know, there's a debt there that is going to be repaid by them. Then we can move forward.

KIRK: Do you know, they started mentioning impeachment in April of 2016 before he was even the nominee. Mark Levin mentioned that in his new book. It's amazing.

CARTER: Oh, yes.

HILTON: It's all about -- we've got to leave it there for a moment. That's what it is all about. They cannot stand the fact that ...

KIRK: That's right.

HILTON: ... that the disrupter, the people's representative, came in, took power that they thought was rightfully theirs away from them and they'd do anything to get it back. It's so disgusting.

CARTER: And it's going to backfire.

HILTON: Right. Okay. I think we're in agreement there. Coming up, a part of my conversation with President Trump that you haven't seen before. We talked about the latest in the Boeing scandal. And coming up next, swamp watch update, that's next.

HILTON: My conversation with President Trump last week covered a wide range of topics and we squeezed as much as we could into last week's show. But one part we didn't have time for was our discussion of the recent controversy surrounding Boeing. Take a look.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

HILTON: Another example of the swamp, you know, people really related to that argument that you made. You see it now with what's going on with Boeing, right?

You talked about the military industrial complex. We know that their planes -- the civilian planes -- but they're a big part of that government machinery. What do you think of what's going on there?

I mean, every day, it seems like we get a story about Boeing. But it's very worrying in terms of what they may have covered up.

DONALD TRUMP (R), PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Well, I feel very badly for Boeing. I think it's one of the great brands of the world and I've never seen a brand be hurt so badly so fast. That 737 MAX has been a disaster for them. And I guess, they're doing a lot of things. But, you know --

HILTON: What do you think of the CEO?

TRUMP: Well, I know him.

HILTON: Are you confident he is the right guy to lead that company out of this?

TRUMP: Well, he was flawless until about four months ago, when that first plane went down, and I've been saying it. They're making it too complicated. You know, they want to be pilots you want to have -- they're making airplanes and other equipment.

I could tell you stories about ships that we're building. They always think they have to up it, up it up it and eventually, I mean, you have to graduate first in your class at MIT to fly an airplane.

They're making it too complicated and what they're doing is making it too dangerous. It's no good. And I told that to Dennis Muilenburg at Boeing who you're talking about.

Dennis is a good man. He has had a great career and the last four months have been a disaster for him.

HILTON: So you've got Nikki Haley on the board there.

TRUMP: Yes.

HILTON: What would you hope that she'd be doing?

TRUMP: Well, I think she can help him a lot. She is very talented. She is a good person. She was great with me and did a really good job at the United Nations. She has already supported us.

But I think she can do a good job. I think it's good to have her on the Board. I think she can help.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HILTON: All right, that's our original Boeing swamp watch. New details have emerged about the faulty technology in their 737 MAX airplane.

It turns out that Boeing knew about a problem with safety features before the two crashes that killed hundreds of innocent people. In 2017, their engineers discovered a problem with the key safety indicator months before delivering their first 737 MAX planes to clients.

Boeing conducted an internal safety review, decided the problem was no big deal and chose not to communicate the problem to their clients or regulators at the FAA, until of course hundreds of people were killed.

Then they thought it might be worth disclosing the flaw. But even after reviewing the issue, the FAA declared the issue to be, quote, "low risk." And that's not all.

Recently unveiled audio recordings from a private meeting show that the American Airlines Pilot Union confronted Boeing executives of a possible safety issues in the 737 MAX just a few months before the deadly crash in Ethiopia.

All of this raises new questions about what else Boeing has known and failed to disclose about the safety of their planes. Look, Boeing is a great American company with many thousands of workers who are among the best in the world. But Boeing leadership is obviously now crooked, self- serving, and shockingly irresponsible. They must be held accountable.

All right, Charlie you followed this all along, what do you think?

KIRK: Yes, and it's really important to realize, this is not the market at work. This is cronyism at work. And you look at the self-dealing, it's the perfect way to put it. The access to government contracts, the monopolization they have on the American manufacturing industry, for airlines. There's only really two firms in the world that can make the type of planes that they make the transcontinental airlines, and that would be Airbus in France and Boeing in America.

And I like to think that we're a country that's so rich, a $20 trillion GDP, 330 million Americans. We have one company that can do that. That just goes to show that the tax dollars should be always diffused and decentralized when you bid for these contracts.

HILTON: Such an important point. That's so much the thing that's gone wrong in so many parts of the economy, the centralization, not enough competence.

KIRK: Yes.

CARTER: That's so true. And I think for me, you know, I fly frequently, you fly frequently. We put our lives in the hands of these companies. This is about -- not just about a flaw in something that will harm anyone. This is about hundreds of people on board an aircraft, with their children, with their family members, entrusting their lives to the people who make these planes.

And unfortunately, for Boeing and their executives, just as you said, Steve, they withheld information that could have saved people's lives. I mean, this is probably one of the most grotesque moves a company like this could make.

And you're right, Boeing love Boeing. My father was a mechanic on an aircraft, he worked on AWACS. You know, my father always talked about, you know, the safety issues on a plane.

So for me, to think that Boeing could do that, those are the questions that I want to know. How much more has been withheld from the American public? And what are we expecting of our corporations? And you're right, it's cronyism, but it doesn't stop there. We need to know what's going on and they need to be honest with us.

KIRK: And there's a super deep point here, and you talk about this in your book. When you don't have competition, you get lazy.

CARTER: That's right.

KIRK: You stop being your best version of yourself, so Boeing has not had that kind of competition for years. So they got to this level, where they have endless tax dollars coming, where they spend more money on public affairs and lobbying than on research and development, and then actually making sure their products are the best in the world.

And what you talk about in your book, we've talked about it in the show many times -- decentralization, competition, entrepreneurship -- will make the products better, but also give a better value for the taxpayer and hopefully end up saving lives.

HILTON: And also they're really, really great -- a terrible example of what we talk about all the time it's almost the revolving door, the executive. I mean, they're literally -- I can't remember the exact details, but the Head of Safety at Boeing ends up becoming the Head of Safety at the FAA, the regulators.

CARTER: Research and development -- the problems with that we've seen that not only in the private sector, we've seen it in the public sector, with the Pentagon and with the Department of Defense, where you have, you know, these contracts that are these open-ended contracts with very few bidders, with very little competition and people are putting out products that are sub because there is just not competition out there to put out the best product.

KIRK: I would venture a guess that if President Trump did a press conference and he said, "The $10 billion," whatever it is, "Will now be open bid." You'll have entrepreneurs from all over our country saying, "I'll do it. I have expertise. I used to work for Boeing. I can have a competitor." Allow the market to solve these problems. Don't rely on Washington, D.C. to do it.

HILTON: That's a great idea. For anyone who is watching with the power to make that happen, I would say, "Go for it."

All right, coming up, our interview with President Trump made headlines for his comments on everything from Iran to Mayor Pete, up next.

I want to break down some of the key moments and explain what they tell us about this President. Don't go away.

HILTON: So last week, I had the chance to talk to President Trump about everything from domestic policy to foreign relations to his approach to doing the job.

Now, I just want to pull out a couple of the highlights from the interview. Because I think it tells you something really important about this President and something that you just not recognize elsewhere in the media.

First of all, let's look at this answer about Iran.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: When I first came to office, one of the first meetings I had was at the Pentagon with generals and they were showing me the Middle East. And they had 14 or 15 sites where there was nothing but war problems. Every single one of those sites was instigated by Iran.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HILTON: All right, so what does that tell you? We keep hearing the whole time, he doesn't listen to his people around him. He doesn't read briefings. He just sort of watches TV. Total rubbish.

In response to a question about Iran, he immediately goes to a briefing from the experts and the generals at the Pentagon and remembers the detail really precisely.

So second one, this is about carried interest.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

HILTON: Tax reform, tax cuts -- we all agree it's been an amazing ...

TRUMP: It's been great.

HILTON: ... boost to the economy and so on. There was one thing missing from it that you talked about the people noticed in 2016. Carried interest.

TRUMP: Yes.

HILTON: You describe that as ...

TRUMP: I did.

HILTON: ... getting away with murder.

TRUMP: Yes, I hated it.

HILTON: Why wasn't that tax --

TRUMP: But I traded that for two points. In other words, I could have had carried interest out, but you would have paid 23 or 24 instead of 21. And I wanted the 21 percent. I used that as a negotiating chip, and frankly, was a very good deal.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HILTON: Okay, so let's look at that. He talks about tax reform the whole time, that's in the conversation. This carried interest point that I threw in there, he wasn't expecting that.

No one is talking about that at the moment. That was a debate from two years ago. I threw it in there, he immediately got the point, remembered the detail, got into the whole argument of why it's a good idea, and then in the end, why he decided not to do it.

And this is the person that they accuse of not focusing on detail, not understanding policy, being basically some kind of sort of dummy that doesn't understand.

You know, it's really fascinating -- the grasp of policy detail, evident in that answer in his instant response to an unexpected question like that, I thought was really, really important for everyone to understand.

And then finally, this one on tweeting and watching TV and all the rest of it.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

HILTON: That's one of the things you get hit for a lot about how you do the job. They say, "He is up in the residence all morning watching TV, rage-tweeting at 'Morning Joe,' he is not focusing on the job." What's your response to that?

TRUMP: So I have way over a hundred million people on the various things, much more than that, but over 100 million people between Twitter and Facebook and Instagram and all of it, right?

It's a tremendous way to communicate for me, because I have so many people. When people do a book, they beg me, "Please give me --" because it goes to being a bestselling book.

If there's somebody interesting, I like to watch it. I watch much less television, you know, they would like to make me look like I'm up early in the morning. I'm in the Oval Office early. I leave late.

HILTON: So it's not true when they say that you're up in the residence.

TRUMP: No, no. They do that as a form of disparagement. I was about -- three weeks ago with some very big businessmen, I was in the Oval Office negotiating. And we have a small screen of television, and they noticed that they were saying, "Donald Trump is up now. He is steaming. He is angry. He is up in the residence." I said, "See that, folks. I'm in the Oval Office."

HILTON: Right.

TRUMP: I'm a very calm person, too, you know. They like to make me like I'm raging. I'm like the raging bull. I'm a raging person --

HILTON: The tweets are a bit raging every now and again.

TRUMP: No, but sometimes you do that for a reason. I mean, you know, the tweets seem to work.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HILTON: So what does that tell us? This is not some impulsive lunatic as the as the resistance maniacs describe him. This is someone who is incredibly intentional and strategic about how he does the job, what he values, how he wants to operate, how he wants to communicate, fully aware of what he is doing.

I just thought when you take it all together, the briefings and the policy grasp and all the rest of it, I just wanted to make those points, not necessarily about the specifics of each of those policy areas, but what it tells you about this President is the direct opposite of what you hear all the time from his critics, okay.

CARTER: Look, I think the most important thing -- and the American people that voted for President Trump got this right off the bat -- he listens. He doesn't want to be bamboozled. He doesn't want people to come into the Pentagon and sit down and tell him about every single tribe in Syria, and the machinations between them.

He wants to hear what is going on, and he heard it clearly. All of these areas -- Iran. Iran was involved in, in making a problem for us in the Middle East and are affecting our national security. He sees the problem, he makes a decision, and he negotiates.

This is a perfect example, Steve, of why he won. Because people get that. When he talks to an audience, he is able to deliver a message and the American people sitting there that are listening to him says, "For the first time, here is somebody who is not playing me."

HILTON: Yes, that's right.

CARTER: "He is telling me like it is and then he is holding to that promise and moving forward." And really, that's what the Democrats hate about him most.

KIRK: He is absolutely brilliant. I say that commonly. I just want to reinforce that. Look at the different topics you were throwing at him, Steve, and he was able to lean back two years ago and use exactly why he had that specific policy position and what he got in response for it.

And he is so quick. He is relentless. But you look at what he has been able to accomplish with the amount thrown at him. I don't think that combination has ever happened in American history where you have this level of accomplishment with that level of adversity to get through it.

And I will say, those three examples that you used with the Iran, how we listened to the generals, they have to process information, then make a decision - the correct decision without having to just immediately step into conflict or war, but have other steps before that, which deserves to be praised and heralded.

But also the carried interest, which was really interesting. He is able to say, "No, no, I use that as a negotiating tactic. I got a lower tax rate because of it." And I think it's such a disservice the media does when they described this President.

CARTER: And certainly the third with the Twitter, you know, how he utilizes Twitter.

KIRK: Yes, I love it.

CARTER: And these different platforms to be very strategic.

HILTON: This is what I find so -- truly unfair about the reporting on him because it's one thing to disagree with his policy positions and say, you know, that's not what this anything is about.

KIRK: No.

HILTON: They constantly --

KIRK: It's ad hominem attacks.

HILTON: That's all it is. That's all it ever is. There's never any recognition that actually what he's going -- what? To get elected President from nowhere.

KIRK: Steve, do you ever notice --

HILTON: The idea that you're some sort of dummy, which is what they try and make out.

KIRK: Every day, it's contradictory ad hominem attacks. One day, he has no idea what he is doing; the other day, he is this mad scientist destroying the country.

CARTER: That's right.

KIRK: One day, he is clueless and the other day he has this Machiavellian plan to uproot America. You can't be both a mad scientists and also clueless.

HILTON: Right.

CARTER: That's right. And also targeting his family. It's a consistent targeting. They're trying to isolate him. They target the people around him, those that were in his administration in the beginning, then they go after his family.

But you know what's so brilliant about President Trump -- and in history, they will write about this -- that he continues to do the work for the American people, despite all of these attacks, he is able to keep himself straightforward, level-headed, moving forward and despite everything that they throw at him, he has been able to do incredible things for this country.

HILTON: Yes, and they want to continue, too, even though you know, literally, this week, when you've got, you know, the kind of investigative sort of mania of the Democrats, leading to the sort of blow up we saw, they're still going to be pushing ahead with things that they can do with the executive action.

I was just really pleased. And I got a lot of good feedback from you. Thank you for that on the interview last Sunday. And I really appreciate that. And one thing that a lot of you said was that it was great to see the President given some time to breathe and to express his views in a kind of considered way on a range of issues and that was exactly my intention. So thank you very much for all your feedback on that.

Coming up, Linda McMahon weighs in on the 2020 election and her time in President Trump's Cabinet -- my exclusive interview, next.

HILTON: I recently spoke with former Small Business Administration Chief, Linda McMahon about her time in President Trump's Cabinet and her new position as Head of the America First Super PAC. Take a look.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

HILTON: Linda McMahon, great to see you. I'm dying to ask you so many questions. I want to start with your experience in President Trump's Cabinet focusing on small business, what were your priorities? What were you focusing on when you were in that role?

LINDA MCMAHON, HEAD, AMERICA FIRST SUPER PAC: Well, I can tell you, I had a tremendous good time being at SBA, but also it was incredibly beneficial for me to be able to go all over the country.

I went to all 50 states. I visited all 68 district offices for SBA, and in that tour, and the reason I did that was because I really wanted to hear from small businesses. I mean, I, as the head of the SBA was the advocate for small businesses in Washington, and so I talked to over 800 business owners, I went to dozens of businesses all around the country.

And so what I heard from them are the benefits of tax cuts we're bringing to them, to be able to write off in a purchase of equipment, et cetera in the year which they were buying it to expand, hire more people raise wages, regulatory rollback, all of that was so important so I was bringing those messages back to Washington.

HILTON: And the regulatory stuff, like you, I've started and run my own business, not on the scale of yours, but you know, I've done my bit. And it's the regulatory stuff that just is so irritating and gets in the way.

Just talk to us a little bit about some of the specific stories you heard about the things that have changed to make small business owners' lives easier.

MCMAHON: Well, what I heard, mostly, when I was out meeting with small businesses was not necessarily any particular regulation. It was actually the cumulative amount of regulation. So you have a small business owner that is often the CEO and the janitor, and so you don't often have time to do all of the things that are necessary to comply with all of the regulations and you might not even know about all of them.

So I think actually rolling back regulations, making the paperwork of requirements so much less is giving entrepreneurs more time to spend and focus on their businesses and they're able to grow.

HILTON: I remember when I was engaged in a very similar program back in the U.K. government many years ago trying to roll back regulations and I was saying to the officials in some of the departments. Well, why don't we just, you know, get -- rather than trying to find the specific ones we want to get rid of, why don't we just reset the default? Get rid of all of them and then see what happens for a year. And then bring back the ones that we feel that we really need. Now, just remember, the kind of complete horror at this idea?

MCMAHON: That would have been, I think, horrific, but I do think the approach that the President has taken and that each agency has taken and then as the regulatory rolled back out into the private sector has been successful, has been, you know, the right approach, because it's really, really been successful.

HILTON: So let's look ahead to 2020 now in your new role. One of the things that is just getting all the attention apart from the candidates on the Democratic side, we may get to that in a second, but there's a lot of focus on those particular voters that President Trump won over in those particular states, you know, sometimes called I think a little insultingly, the rust belt states.

But we talk about Pennsylvania, Wisconsin, Michigan, particularly; Pennsylvania, especially. That kind of economic argument there was so important in 2016. Do you think that he'll be able to make that case to them again in 2020?

MCMAHON: Oh, absolutely because it's been successful. I mean, look at you know, the first time in decades, wage growth has actually happened. There wasn't a wage growth; now, there is wage growth, the best in 10 years.

And so workers are definitely feeling that. And when I often hear Democrats talk about how well the tax cuts and everything just benefited the upper income earners that is just not true. That lower 25 percent really had better benefit, you know, than anyone else across the spectrum.

HILTON: What do you think of those who say, "Well, yes," but you've got a couple of the candidates in this vast and growing Democratic field that may pose a problem there for slightly different reasons.

First of all, they talk about Joe Biden having a particular appeal in those kind of states to those kind of workers, the more blue collar appeal, but also Bernie Sanders, because there are a lot of voters in that category who actually interestingly, crossed over and voted for Bernie in the Democratic primary and then switched to Trump in the general election because they wanted that kind of populist message. What do you think about those two, Bernie and Biden?

MCMAHON: Well, it'll be interesting to see how the field actually does narrow in who the candidate is. But I think if you do take a look at former Vice President Biden's record while he was Vice President, again, jobs lost; under President Trump jobs gained. Manufacturing jobs were lost. And so we brought them back.

Really, the feeling of those workers that I think Biden had a great appeal to clearly understand, promises were made, but President Trump delivered.

HILTON: So agree with that. Quickly on Bernie though, what do you think about his appeal to those kind of the Trump base?

MCMAHON: Well, I think, you know, Bernie Sanders just takes us farther and farther to the left and I don't see that we will see the kind of economic growth at all anywhere near. In fact, we'd see the opposite if Bernie Sanders was elected President of the United States.

And Medicare-for-All, while it sounds like a wonderful premise, the real understanding is not there of the -- I think of the detrimental effect that it would actually have on healthcare available to everyone around the country, because the quality of that care, the lack of numbers of doctors that we would need in our country, we're already at a doctor shortage. This would not accomplish what Bernie Sanders wants to do, and our economy would definitely go the other direction.

HILTON: Which those people definitely don't want. I think the President is very grateful I'm sure to have you on his team now looking to 2020. Wonderful to talk to you today. Linda McMahon, thank you so much.

MCMAHON: Thank you so much.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

HILTON: Coming up, if San Francisco in California are any indication of having a loony left in charge of the country is a scary proposition. The loony left is next.

HILTON: The City of San Francisco has long been home to the most left-wing politics in the country, yet a recent piece in "The Washington Post" quotes, "Longtime residents calling the city a train wreck," and highlights many attributes that are the opposite of what progressives say they stand for. The downfall of San Francisco is tonight's loony left.

All right, here's a quote from that "Washington Post" piece. "To take a midday tour downtown is to be enveloped by a jeaned and athleisured army of young workers mostly white and Asian and predominantly male. The presence of a boomer or toddler is akin to spotting an endangered species."

The city is too homogenous, too expensive, too tech, too millennial, too white, too elite, too bro. I can add to that from personal experience over many years, the entire city stinks of feces, urine and weed. Drug paraphernalia can be found on every street corner, homeless people lining the sidewalks, potholes puncture the roads. And yet the housing is so expensive.

Regular working Americans with jobs in the city often have two or even three hour commutes from somewhere affordable. San Francisco is a civic catastrophe. And it is entirely the responsibility of the Democrats and the self-righteous big tech overlords who slavishly back them.

They've been in sole control of state and local government for over a decade. There's no one else to blame. God help us all if this goes national.

CARTER: And we're seeing it. God help us all of this goes national, but we're seeing it. We're seeing it spread. Unfortunately, you know, when you think about this, it's so tragic. It's so horrible that when people from other countries get to San Francisco and walk out on the streets, and they're expecting to see this booming, beautiful city on the hill. They see feces. They see homelessness. They see people with mental illness just rummaging around in the streets looking through trash for food.

And what they don't see is a middle class America, or low income America, they see the rich and the poor. What does that say about us? And all of the people that have fled, and even in California now, even in Los Angeles, we're seeing it. We're seeing the remnants of this. We're seeing it in Washington, D.C. in some cases. There has to be something -- something needs to be done and I think everybody knows it.

HILTON: And I think it's really important to focus the conversation on this, which is that this is not an accident. This is not an act of nature. This is the consequence of the policies of the loony left.

KIRK: Right. And so this is by design. The left will create policies that protects the ruling class, the Wise Men of Washington, the philosopher kings, the elites, as we call them. And then they will then point to the inequality that they created as a reason to give themselves more power.

And then the inequality will be exacerbated, then they'll say, "We need more power, because look at all the inequality." So then it will be exacerbated even further and then that's what you have the implementation of socialism where the ruling elites, the philosopher Kings, are able to live in permanent luxury, while pointing to the inequality that they themselves created as the reason why they need to stay in power.

HILTON: Exactly.

CARTER: Absolutely, absolutely. I mean, what you'll see is to, is the migration. So once they wreaked havoc in one area, then they move and they move to another area saying, "Whoa, this is just too much taxes on our business. We need to move out of here. Let's move to Arizona. Let's move to Nevada. Let's move to Utah." And then they start voting for the same policies there creating this same problems in those communities that they created in San Francisco.

KIRK: And Steve, it's all about mobility. America has always been about mobility that's why this country is the greatest country ever to exist. There's nothing mobile about San Francisco, about an income tax rate where people can't keep the money that they're earning. Sales tax, property tax, schools that are not working or functioning. Civil institutions are crumbling, and the elites can afford to price themselves out of it, though.

They can afford to send their kids to the private schools. They can afford to have the private jets to go to better communities. It's the middle class Americans that crumble under these policies.

HILTON: Yes. And that's, again, make the political connections. So many of these policies are driven by the public sector unions that absolutely control the Democrats in this state of California where we are tonight and around the country, too.

All right, coming up another Democrat jumps into the 2020 race, which if my math is correct, makes him the 257th declared candidate. We will tell you it is, next.

HILTON: Welcome back, everyone. Because of our interview with President Trump last week, we couldn't bring you our weekly 2020 update and let you know that yes, you guessed it, the Democratic field has grown even larger.

The newest candidate, New York City Mayor, Bill de Blasio. The President weighed in and I think it's safe to say, he isn't a fan.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: I can't believe it. I just heard that the worst mayor in the history of New York City and without question, the worst mayor in the United States is now running for President. It will never happen, I'm pretty good at predicting things like that. I would be very surprised to see him in there for a long period, but it's just not going to happen.

If you like high taxes and if you like crime, you could vote for him, but most people aren't into that. So I wish him luck, but really, it would be better off if you get back to New York City and did your job for the little time you have left. Good luck. Be well.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HILTON: We all really enjoyed that. I think, it feels like we should just leave it there, but you know --

KIRK: He is the best, isn't he?

HILTON: It's just so great.

KIRK: The worst mayor of New York City and probably the worst mayor in the country. He is exactly right. Imagine being the worst at something and then want to be President, that's Mayor de Blasio.

CARTER: He could win an award for being the worst at something. I mean, all you have to do is walk down the city streets of New York now and see how much it's changed since he's become mayor.

I mean the poverty, the people sleeping on the streets, the sidewalks, the crime. He seems to care more about what people eat in New York City and how big their Big Gulps are and whether or not they could buy a --

KIRK: Not to mention, he screwed up the Amazon deal.

CARTER: That's right.

KIRK: He has been raising taxes.

CARTER: Horrible.

KIRK: The schools are totally crumbling. He has lost the trust of the police and anyone -- and you can have that street feel when you go to New York.

CARTER: Yes, that's right.

KIRK: The ethic, the spirit of New York is not there anymore. It was different under Giuliani.

CARTER: That's right. Absolutely.

HILTON: But it's amazing to me that he is universally despised. It's really interesting like -- even his own side. They just can't stand him and I just saw going to a friendly news outlet you know, where they will get completely kind of slavish treatment generally speaking, and they were confronting him with a disaster of New York and his appalling poll ratings, you know, no one likes him.

CARTER: Which is really fascinating, because now that's the one thing that those news outlets and President Trump can agree on. So Bill de Blasio has done one thing. He has got an agreement between President Trump and those news outlets that are more to the left.

But you know, if you're thinking about New York City, and you're thinking about the changes, you brought it up, Charlie, Rudy Giuliani imagine how much of a change that was.

I remember going to New York when he was the mayor and just being like, the city is beautiful.

KIRK: He had a great spirit to it.

CARTER: I felt comfortable walking around at night, yes, it had a great spirit. People were proud. Now even New Yorkers don't like Mayor de Blasio.

KIRK: And to this day, Giuliani never got credit for what he did after 9/11 to bring that city together. And Trump played a big role in that. People forget, he donated millions of dollars and was a huge part of the reconstruction and the cleanup project in New York. And now it's too bad because New York is really the center of the world. That's really what was said all throughout the 60s, 70s and 80s.

And now it's just become really a place of high tax and you want to talk about where those socialist policies are put in place. The elites are doing fine in New York, it's middle class New Yorkers that are suffering.

And the one thing that could have helped them is Amazon coming in with 24,000 jobs and de Blasio wanted nothing to do with it.

HILTON: But it's just amazing to me, like he like why is he bothering? I mean, like the President put it so well, like "Good luck." But why is he - - all of these people are jumping? Like it feels like the field is very, very, you know, the bigger it gets, the more kind of settled it seems in terms of the people who are there at the top.

CARTER: They live in a bubble. This is the problem, Steve. They're not with the rest of America. They don't really even understand what's going on here. That's why they're freaking out in a manner of speaking with President Trump. And they're coming out like Nancy Pelosi and holding those press conferences and talking about obstruction and throwing --

The rest of America isn't even a part of that. So Bill de Blasio, he's a narcissist. He kind of lives in his own bubble. He thinks he is doing the greatest thing in the world for everyone. And he doesn't see the destruction and the havoc that he wreaks as he moves through the city. Like, go ahead and sniff --

KIRK: It literally reeks.

HILTON: All right, well, there we are. Like the streets of San Francisco, reeks.

KIRK: It's unbelievable what's happened to that city.

HILTON: Well, there we go. Loony left for you. Okay, that's all for tonight. Thank you so much for joining us. Thanks to Sara and Charlie. You can learn more about the next revolution.

urn:contentItem:5NDS-G4N1-JCDN-11G7-00000-00Manufacturers, Wall Street getting Trump's ear in first 100 days2017-04-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:08:31ZLexisNexisBUSINESSManufacturers, Wall Street getting Trump's ear in first 100 days

WASHINGTON: Manufacturers and Wall Street have led the quest for business access to President Donald Trump in his first 100 days in office, with media companies and Silicon Valley seldom entering the presidential bubble, a Reuters review found. Since inauguration day on Jan. 20, top executives from at least 186 companies have visited with Trump or senior advisers at the White House or on presidential trips, including those to Mar-a-Lago, the private, seaside Florida club where he spends many weekends. Some of the meetings have been reported in the press.

But Reuters analyzed more than 900 White House press pool reports to give the first big picture view, albeit an incomplete one, of who has had the most and least success at bending the president's ear. Such access can be crucial for companies, with Trump regularly passing judgment and making proposals on business issues such as trade, taxes, immigration and regulation. The review showed Trump listening closely to some segments of Corporate America, though perhaps neglecting the dynamic technology and entertainment sectors, both powerful U.S. export industries. Tim Cook, CEO of Apple Inc , and other tech leaders met with Trump before his inauguration. Access sometimes means influence, but it was likely too soon to tell, after less than 100 days, whether Trump's actions have disproportionately favored big manufacturers and Wall Street. Industrial power-houses have led the way on access, including companies with the clout to make significant hiring decisions: Ford Motor Co CEO Mark Fields has met with Trump at least four times; General Motors CEO Mary Barra, at least four times; and Boeing representatives, at least three times. The Reuters review helps fill a blank in the Trump record that opened in mid-April when he put the White House visitor logs off-limits to the public. They had been mostly public under Obama. Transparency advocates have warned that Trump's decision will make it harder to hold him accountable. "A public record of who has the president's ear is more important than it has ever been," said John Wonderlich, executive director of the Sunlight Foundation, a nonprofit good-government advocacy group. The review showed about half of the companies that have made it into the Trump inner circle through April 21, day 92 of his presidency, were manufacturers or financial firms - asset managers, insurers and banks ranging from Wall Street giants such as Citigroup to small community banks. Financier Stephen Schwarzman, who chairs a presidential advisory forum of business leaders, is CEO of the Blackstone Group , the largest manager of private equity and real estate assets. He was spotted by the press pool aboard Air Force 1 on Feb. 3 when the president was traveling to Mar-a-Lago. Schwarzman also attended at least three meetings with Trump and other executives. Almost all of Trump's meetings were group encounters with 10 or more executives sitting down with the president and White House officials in events billed as listening sessions, roundtable discussions or town halls. A few were more intimate encounters, such as on March 18, when Ike Perlmutter, CEO of Marvel Entertainment, a Walt Disney Corp. subsidiary, met with the president in Mar-a-Lago before having dinner with the president, first lady Melania Trump and Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross. Perlmutter, however, was one of few executives from media companies seen by pool reporters in meetings with Trump. Information technology firms, which enjoyed significant access to former President Barack Obama, have had less access to Trump than legacy manufacturers such as auto and steel makers. IBM CEO Ginni Rometty attended three meetings with Trump, but was one of only a few CEOs from big tech firms seen at the White House. Manufacturers and financiers also enjoyed access to the White House under Obama, according to a Reuters review in December 2015 of White House visitor logs. The recent Reuters review is not comprehensive since the press pool, though dogged and alert, may have missed some of Trump's meetings with business leaders. The pool is a rotation of journalists from several outlets, including Reuters, who follow Trump and get briefings from White House officials on some, but not all of his meetings. (Reporting by Jason Lange in Washington; Additional reporting by Noel Randewich in San Francisco; Editing by Kevin Drawbaugh and Dan Grebler) - Reuters

urn:contentItem:5588-7261-DYRW-V092-00000-00MANY BIG TECH PR FIRMS UP 20 PERCENT2012-03-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:08:31ZLexisNexisPg. 1MANY BIG TECH PR FIRMS UP 20 PERCENT

PR firms either specializing in tech or with big tech practices showed major growth in 2011 as tech companies grappled with selling and explaining complicated products to a blizzard of audiences, according to the O'Dwyer technology rankings released today.

Edelman, whose overall growth rate in 2011 was +15.9% to $604 million, had a 24.3% spurt in tech to $126,752,418.

Others big gainers included:

APCO Worldwide, +24.6% to $31,080,000

Atomic PR, +35% to $12,006,603

Sparkpr, +17% to $10,396,043

Davies Murphy Group, +36% to $8,883,415

Airfoil PR, +19% to $8,127,627

MWW Group, +16% to $7,603,000

Launch Squad, + 30% to $7,573,405

Merritt Group, +15.7% to $6,573,638

Allison + Partners, + 30% to $6,300,000

Makovsky + Co., +66% to $3,000,000

Borders & Gratehouse, +66% to $2,337,557

Bateman Group, +28% to $2,337,557

Catapult PR-IR, +24% to $1,044,924.

Demand High for Tech PR

"Technology has transcended IT," said Pete Peterson, global technology chair of Edelman.

"It now impacts every facet of our lives and is fundamentally changing nearly every industry," he added. "As a result, tech companies must now engage with an ever growing number of customers and stakeholders. As consultants, our mission is to help clients navigate this complexity in a way that drives positive commercial, reputational and regulatory outcomes."

Kimberly Davis, senior VP and head of the technology practice of Waggener Edstrom Worldwide, which had $59,305,000 in tech fees, said the firm "Touches every level of the IT technology stack from silicon up to the application layer.

"We work with innovators in 'new' industries such as clean energy and 'old' industries such as aerospace, telecommunications and diagnostic imaging. We help deliver in-depth stories around innovation and change that move markets and crown leaders...we help companies to shift the industry dialogue, drive adoption of new products and ideas, and, ultimately achieve real and lasting business success--increased sales," she said.

Aedhmar Hynes, CEO of Text 100, which grew 10% to $50,425,771, said the firm has invested heavily in developing integrated marketing and communications services to meet the demand for social media and digital expertise from clients and prospects.

She said Text 100's "core expertise" in tech has been applied to adjacent markets such as energy, automotive, aviation, travel and tourism.

"By expanding beyond the tech sector, we have been able to market our integrated services to a new range of prospects leading to growth in all major regions--Asia Pacific, Europe, Middle East and Africa and North America," she said.

APCO Sees Global Need; Atomic Up 35%

Garry Walsh, APCO's managing director for Southeast Asia and global lead on the firm's work for Microsoft, said the technology sector worldwide is going through a "complex period of tremendous change."

"We have seen growth and deregulation in some areas coupled with increased scrutiny and regulation in others," he added. "What is clear is that no other industry is as fast-moving as the technology sector. The ability to anticipate new trends in business is especially critical to this sector. We have many years of experience advising some of the world's largest players in this industry and we also work with clients in the start-up and early phases of development."

Andy Getsey, co-founder and CEO of Atomic PR, said its 35% growth was propelled by new clients in consumer tech as well as specialized tech.

The "pure consumer" assignments came from clients such as Bertazzoni and Cabot Creamery.

Growth is also coming from the firm's "broadening, creative and effective use of analytics and the launch of sister agency H3O Communications."

All-Tech Firms Prosper

Good years were posted by many firms only doing tech including Borders + Gratehouse, San Francisco, growing 66% to $2,982,627.

Founded in 2008 by Emily Borders, Kathleen Gratehouse and Carol Carrubba, the principals say it practices "smart, controlled growth" which means "evaluating each prospect and building partnerships with clients focused on collaboration, creativity and a shared definition of success."

"We provide innovative service offerings like content development, social media and data campaigns that differentiate and create meaningful business results for our portfolio of high growth clients," said Carrubba.

Others with all-tech practices include Spark PR, Hoffman Agency, Davis Murphy Group, Airfoil PR, Horn Group, Launch Squad, Matter Communications, Trylon SMR and Catapult PR-IR.

Social Media "Craze" Deplored by Trufelman

Lloyd Trufelman, president of Trylon SMR, New York, said too many PR pros "have gone crazy over social media often at the expense of mainstay media." Some marketers have even turned entirely to Facebook and Twitter without any PR expertise in the mix, he said.

"Most viral news memes still originate and/or are amplified via mainstream digital and analog platforms," he added. "The explosion of media outlets requires that PR efforts be spread across multiple platforms. Almost everything is promotable now because there are media channels interested in reporting on topics no matter how obscure."

"Another trend that might be heading in the wrong direction," he continued, "is the rush by PR pros to get into content creation. Until recently, this was called 'advertorial.' Clients want it and it can generate lots of billable hours but it doesn't create valid third party credibility."

Edelman, New York, $126,752,418

Pete Pederson, global technology chair at Edelman, said "At the core of Edelman's tech practice are people who deeply understand the bits and the bytes. It's a nuanced environment and one that changes very quickly, so we place a high value on talent with real tech chops. If we're doing our jobs right, we're just as likely to be giving counsel to engineers and developers as we are to the communications team. In tech, what a company says and what it actually does need to be tightly aligned.

"While technical acumen gives us credibility, it's our integrated approach that drives value for Edelman clients. We frequently draw on world-class expertise in social media, brand marketing, healthcare, public affairs and corporate communications to field diverse teams that think through client challenges in new and interesting ways. For example, we recently developed a special unit focused on Data Security & Privacy. In this space, the issues are layered and intricate, thus requiring a blend of skill sets."

"From innovative startups to well-established market leaders, our philosophy is the same: Put the client first, build the right team, align on objectives, and commit to mutual success."

Waggener Edstrom WW, Bellevue, WA, $59,305,000

Kimberly Davis, senior VP and head of the technology practice, said the firm, with 28 years of experience in the technology sector, "is at the fore-front of important technological advances that change the world. Our vision--to be the recognized leader in communicating world-changing innovations that influence markets, inspire people and improve lives--guides the work we do with world-leading brands including 3M, GE Healthcare, HIT, MercyCorps, Texas Instruments DLP and T-Mobile USA.

"From GUI to 64-bit computing, aeronautics to photovoltaic, it's all part of our vernacular and skill set.

"We help standards bodies and trade associations promulgate new standards, align with regulatory agencies and build global markets," said WaggEd's Davis. "We've been to Switzerland with the world Radio Congress to discuss spectrum allocation, involved at foundational levels with hot-button issues such as digital broadcast standards, and helped clients define next-generation solutions that shape how technology is created, deployed and utilized. Technology innovation is truly our heritage and our passion."

Text 100 Global PR, New York, $50,425,771

Aedhamar Hynes, CEO, said the firm has invested heavily in the past few years in developing integrated marketing and communications services to meet the increasing demands for social media and digital expertise from clients and prospects.

"Digital is now core to everything we do at Text 100," she said. "As a result, we have been able to successfully integrate social media and digital strategy into programs with existing clients and us this expertise to capitalize on new opportunities with a growing range of prospects spanning across multiple industry sectors."

APCO Worldwide, Washington, D.C., $31,080,000

Gary Walsh, managing director for Southeast Asia and global lead on APCO's work for Microsoft, said the firm has been supporting and advising Microsoft since 2001 on corporate citizenship, regulatory matters, government relations and communications across markets in Asia, Europe, Africa and the Americas. Other tech clients include eBay and Hewlett Packard.

"Our tech practice had another successful year in 2011 with significant new client projects won around the world and the expansion of several existing accounts to new markets. A good example of the latter is our work for Applied Materials, the worldwide manufacturer of solar cell, semi-conductor and micro-chip production machineries. Over the past few years we have had great success supporting their government relations priorities in the European Union and 2011 saw our account expand to provide strategic counsel and regulatory consulting to help them grow their business in China."

Atomic PR, San Francisco, $12,006,603

Andy Getsey, co-founder and CEO, said the firm's growth in 2011 was due to its "broadening, creative and effective use of analytics as well as the launch of sister agency H3O Communications.

"These two things led to a string of tech and consumer tech wins by both firms, kicked off by McAfee and Sony early in the year, and a growing number of pure consumer assignments from brands like Bertazzoni and Cabot Creamery going into the end of the year," he said.

Sparkpr, San Francisco, $10,396,043

Alan Soucy, CEO of Sparkpr, which has specialized in tech since its founding in 1999, said it has handled clients ranging from stealth start-ups to Fortune 500 global public companies. "We have supported tech companies through launches, growth, and acquisitions and IPOs and we're known for our expertise in social media programs," he said.

Specialized practice areas focus on consumer tech, digital media & advertising, ecommerce, enterprise & IT, financial services, gaming, green tech, media & entertainment, mobile & wireless, music, social media and venture capital.

Current clients include Barclaycard US, blinkx, Etsy, Good Technology, Greylock Partners, Hootsuite, NEA, Nielsen, Pinnacle Engines, Rdio, Spiceworks, SugarCRM, "The Today Show," Vevo and Virgin Green Fund.

Sparkpr won TechCrunch's 'Crunchie Award' for best overall U.S. technology firm. Inc Magazine has named it one of the fastest growing privately held companies three years in a row and the San Francisco Business Times in 2010 and 2011 recognized it as one of the Bay Area's "Best Places to Work."

Branch offices are in New York, London and Cape Town.

Davies Murphy Group, Burlington, MA, $8,883,415

"At Davies Murphy Group, tech PR isn't one of our practice areas - it's our only practice area," says founder Eric Davies.

He explained the firm's operation: "We work with technology giants like IBM and Comcast, as well as earlier stage companies like Veeam and Brainshark, and we provide a wide range of services including PR (media relations, analyst relations, social media, speaking programs, and awards programs), marketing (lead generation programs, collateral development, event management, messaging and positioning, SEO/SEM), and business strategy (product strategy, market development, M&A strategy)."

The agency was started in 1998 with an exclusive focus on technology because, for the previous decade, Davies (whose roots are in IT and software engineering) had been the client of PR agencies, and felt that most agencies weren't well equipped to represent technology companies.

"In today's media environment, where so much of the emphasis is on content creation, and so much of the coverage depends on being able to tie clients' technologies to industry issues and trends, you really can't staff or operate a tech PR agency the way you would a "consumer or general purpose PR agency," says Davies.

"You need senior, experienced people who not only understand PR and marketing, but who have a real in-depth understanding of a broad range of technologies."

Finn Partners, New York, $8,700,000

Practice heads Howard Solomon, Managing Partner, and Alicia Young, Managing Partner, said "Exceeding client expectations is the hallmark of the Finn Partners technology team. It includes the dedicated mobile/telecom group led by industry figure Christine Bock.

"We work with companies--large and lean, storied and start-up--that share a common objective: to build and mold our technological future," said Solomon.

Both Solomon and Young are strategic counselors and program execution partners. "Our track record is that we deliver award-winning programs and measurable results that serve client business goals and positively impact their bottom line."

Recent clients range from Marvell and IEEE to Logitech, Rovi, AVG, and Carbonite.

Solomon and Young say today's environment requires a PR firm that is a true partner, providing not only functional components, but the insights and innovative thinking to guide often complex technology campaigns. "We partner where we can make a difference, with our feet firmly set in the present, but our imaginations focused on the future," they said.

LaunchSquad, San Francisco, $7,573,405

Jason Mandell, co-founder and partner, said, "The PR landscape is changing dramatically, and for obvious reasons technology PR is at the forefront of that. In the face of this change, agencies must be nimble, cutting edge, and innovative in the way we're getting our clients' messages across. We can't just give lip service to it; we need to build our businesses around it.

Added Manell: "We're focused on embracing innovation and finding new ways to deliver results and value to clients. We must dive into and understand these new channels, and help our clients participate and lead interactive conversations that exist in our new hyper-digital and social world.

Mandell said the firm has "evolved and enhanced our services in very profound ways" over the past few years. "Over 20% of our staff today is involved full-time in non-traditional PR services such as video production and content marketing," he said. "It's what our clients are looking for, and it's what we need to do if we're going to continue to drive value and results for our clients.

Airfoil Public Relations, Detroit, $8,127,627

Janet Tyler, co-CEO of Airfoil, said the firm added significant new clients as well as organic growth to obtain a 19% gain in 2011. "We made substantial investments toward increasing our social and digital capabilities to provide additional value to our clients and reorganized our business to a portfolio model to better manage existing and new accounts," she said.

Significant investments were made in sales and marketing, introducing a dedicated business development executive, conducting extensive brand evaluation, staff training and incentive programs.

"We also finalized plans for improvements to both domestic offices at Southfield, Mich., and Mountain View, Calif., and laid the groundwork for expansion into international markets [in 2012]," she said.

The Horn Group, San Francisco, $7,900,000

Sabrina Horn, president and CEO, said the "most exciting development" at the firm is its "transition from a pure PR agency to a fully integrated digital communications firm."

"PR can no longer operate in a silo," she said. "Companies today need communications programs that have a stronger connection to their brand and utilize more, and different, channels at different times. That's why we've been growing our Interactive group and working with each employee to ensure that they have the advanced social media skills our clients require."

About 75% of client work involves integrated programs that combine PR, social and interactive services, said Horn, who noted the firm has developed an approach called SENSE that helps clients to strategically apply services and tactics into integrated campaigns that achieve business goals.

Said Horn: "We've even gone so far as to weave our Interactive talent into every client engagement, better supporting our clients' larger marketing efforts."

Horn's sector focus continues to be in digital media/publishing, enterprise/Software as a Service (SaaS) and consumer e-commerce. Recent clients have included the New York Times, ServiceNow and Gannett Corp., along with new additions ParkatmyHouse, Avantgate, Axcient and Savings.com.

"There is a new wind in our sails, both as an industry and as an economy," says Horn. "The upcoming slew of IPOs will create a massive influx of capital to help fund many entrepreneurs and their innovations."

MWW Group, East Rutherford, NJ, $7,603,000

Ephraim Cohen, EVP of technology and digital content, and Eric Villines, senior VP, general manager and deputy head of technology, said MWW approaches content and technology as "two sides of the same problem."

"We understand how technology and content interact with and reinforce each other, and how customers engage with the final product," said Cohen. "We know how to reach the influencers who matter most to the brands that are involved and, more importantly, how to engage them in a meaningful dialogue. We execute this in a context that increases the client's relevance and drives action."

Creative services of MWW are aimed at "driving the big ideas," he said.

Event design and management create consumer and influential experiences; trade, business, consumer media and industry analyst relations target the right influencers; social media drives the conversation; enhancing corporate reputation builds trust; community relations leverages influential consumers for insights and amplification.

"All this is driven by a research-based approach that combines both analytics expertise and survey data to execute and measure programs against measurable business and reputation goals," said Cohen.

Comments from tech firms continue online at http://bit.ly/A55mzQ.
